35166: Krosan Cloudscraper.author: Bbone37
35166: Krosan Cloudscraper.text_parsed:
@Xeddicus_Xor: No. Morphed creatures are nameless, colorless, creatures with no types or abilities. If not, and I had to pay during my upkeep for a morphed guy, wouldn't that kind of tip off what is hiding under there?

And to the nay-sayers about "lack of evasion", did you play during Scourge block? Morph WAS evasion. It was like a game of gambler's dice or something. Someone have 3 morphed dudes, and mana open. They swing. Who do you block? With what? What nasty are you letting through? What ability will the trigger when they flip? That was a great deal of the design of the set. So basically the chance of letting him pass only to have him flip and hit for 13 dmg WAS his evasion.

Granted his morph cost is high, but as others stated Astral slide could take care of that for a cheap fatty. You wouldn't be able to do this as a surprise like I was saying above, but lets assume you play slide T3, play this guy morphed T4 with mana to cycle a land, T5 you're swinging for 13, and evasion or not that is hard to beat.

3/5. Good in block, good for reanimation/Mimeoplasm counters and such. Has a variety of uses, but sadly, playing him for face value usually is not one of them.

39603: Liege of the Axe.author: Arachobia
39603: Liege of the Axe.text_parsed:
Random Card Comment

Strangely, morph went over my head when it came out. By that stage I was still a novice at magic (I must ahve been about 12 or so) and, as far as I was concerned, I just wanted green/red decks that would smash my opponent to death. I had no real interest in combos or sneakiness and I just disliked the morp mechanic.

It was only some expansions later when I pulled an Ixidron from a booster that I began to look at all my morph cards again. By that stage I was becoming more interested alternatives to the direct approach of smashing your opponent down to 0 quickly. In a morph deck, very cheap morphs are useful so the Liege gets a point for having a morph cost cheaper then it's casting cost. I cans ee the idea with him: you attack them with a 2/2 and then unmorph him to have a blocker with vigilance ready for the next turn. I think if printed today he might have had a higher toughness.

He's not terrible, but there are more effective morphers. Sorry Liege of the Axe, I do not think I'll be using you anytime soon.

39603: Liege of the Axe.author: Fanaticmogg
39603: Liege of the Axe.text_parsed: A fairly strong card. While its casting cost is a bit high, as a morph creature it's a nice combat trick. For only two mana it's a surprise 2/3 blocker, which is decent, especially since it was in the block when morph was a major mechanic, so it was able to eat a lot of attacking creatures. Add the fact that it becomes vigilant when morphed, and you've got a good limited card.

39653: Kilnmouth Dragon.author: Tanaka348
39653: Kilnmouth Dragon.text_parsed:
I'd say this was one of the rare amplify creatures that didn't suck, but amplify itself was rare anyway, with only 9 of the suckers. Amplify was definitely a poorly executed mechanic. With most of those things, you had to reveal 2 or 3 creatures to even "break even" and get a creature that was on-curve... if you wanted an actual reward for your hoop jumping, you had to have 3 or 4 matching creatures, and if you wanted more than a minor benefit, that's one more card. And yet their mana costs were mostly 5+, at a point when your hand is unlikely to have many cards in it at all. Of course, a cheap Amplify creature could get pretty swingy/nuts, so I understand there's development issues here. But you find ways to make the cards attractive in a different way.

Sort of like this monster. It's still under-curve without any amplify, which is fine; 7 for 5/5 flying is on the weak side but it's there if it's a choice between that and not casting anything at all, and you're getting some value out of the deal. But with just one dragon you have 7 for 8/8 flying and ping for 3, which is a fantastic deal. Two dragons in hand at the 7 mana mark doesn't happen often, but if it does you've got an insane monster for way under price. Fantastic card.

39707: Defiant Elf.author: TAGVoar
39707: Defiant Elf.text_parsed:
This guy is actually quite amazing. As for the comments stating he is "striktly worse then" other cards is probably one of the dumbest things you can say, especially if you play magic, mainly because the way Magic is designed, every card has a use, and personally, I don't care about Llanowar Elites ability, because, sure, that's a great little "oh, hey, it's late game, why not?" kind of ability, but all I have to say is Immaculate Magistrate, and of course, I am such a hardcore Green Mage, I also have to mention Doubling Season in there. I use this guy, and Llanowar Elite in the same deck. Why? Because it means I have not 1, but 8 possible chances to pull a creature with trample, and as long as my opponent isn't playing something with Banding to stop that trample, I am probably going to beat-them-to-death with one of these guys.
Also, I use him in my White\Green token deck because of the wonderful, (and now totally broken) Concerted Effort. Turn 1, this guy or the Llanowar Elite, Turn 2, Hover Myr, Turn 3, Etched Champion or Skyhunter Skirmisher, then Turn 4 Concerted Effort. Thanks to this guy and\or Llanowar Elite, all my creatures are now Flying, Vigilance, Trample, Double Strikes, or protected from all colors.

This guy is actually quite amazing. 39707: Defiant Elf.author: TDL
39707: Defiant Elf.text_parsed:
It isn't often you find a card that is, in fact, "strictly worse" than another card. As Forgeling has already pointed out, this guy is worse than Llanowar Elite. Often times, you see comments such as: "Time Elemental is strictly worse than Temporal Adept." While I can't think of many situations in which I'd rather have a Time Elemental than a Temporal Adept, the claim that Time Elemental is strictly worse than the adept is incorrect. The Time Elemental has a different mana cost, flying, and a different creature type.
Nitpicking? Yes.
In the case of Defiant Elf and Llanowar Elite, though, the term is applied correctly, making this card a humorous counterexample of power creep.
Edit: @Tagvoar
Llanowar Elite is still strictly better, unless we want to get into the Mind Control Argument. If you want to run a playset of both this and the Elite in your deck, more power to you. It still doesn't change the fact that the Elite has an extra beneficial ability that this card doesn't. Would you argue against me saying that Lightning Bolt is strictly better than Shock because you can run four shocks and four lightning bolts in a deck?

39850: Wall of Deceit.author: Equinox523
39850: Wall of Deceit.text_parsed:
Instead of just berating people for being noobs, I'll explain why this card is good:

1. Even if you just play it face up, not many mono-blue creatures have a staggering 5 toughness for 2 mana. Murmuring Phantasm and Dream Stalker are the only two others I can think of, and both are cards from much later sets. Dream Stalker also has a clause that can make it tough to cast on turn 2 without returning a land to your hand, which is something a blue deck may not want to do. This can stifle big threats and aggressive starts until you have your other defenses in place. This can safely block Giant Solifuge, Boros Reckoner, Wild Nacatl, and many others.

2. When you don't need a blocker and just need another dude, you can play this face down for . Damage used the stack back then, so you could optionally put your 2 damage on the stack, before morphing to absorb damage and return to 0/5. With a low morph cost of a single , this meant you could do this on the same turn fairly easily.

3. Unlike other 0/5 defenders, it can morph itself for 3 later in the game and swing for 2 damage. This can be handy if you want to force through a few extra damage, or use tricks like ninjitsu as mentioned by Opine_Fluke. Furthermore, the morphing makes it colorless in case that becomes relevant for some reason.

4. It supports the strategy of morph decks if you have other morphers. Is your opponent blocking your Akroma, Angel of Fury? Or just this lowly wall? Do you have a Meddling Mage out there they are playing right into? Do they dare attack into what could be Brine Elemental or Rockshard Elemental? While you may think this is trivial, it has the added advantage of being able to survive damage that might be fatal to other, more valuable morphers, if you choose to save it at all.

So yes, this is a fine card. I can understand why a 0/5 defender might look unimpressive at first, but playing against this card will teach you some respect for all the utility it provides.

39888: Goblin Goon.author: jeff-heikkinen
39888: Goblin Goon.text_parsed: Can't complain about a 6/6 for 4 mana when Goblin tokens are so easy to come by, greatly mitigating the drawback. Still, just a little too conditional and comes in just a little too late for most Goblin decks. Though the pricier Siege-Gang Commander certainly gets played, that's a lot harder to entirely get rid of and gets at least as much overall damage in, more reliably, if it lives a turn or two. Overall, probably better replaced by a cheaper Goblin in most serious Goblin decks, but kind of fun at casual tables.

Overall, probably better replaced by a cheaper Goblin in most serious Goblin decks, but kind of fun at casual tables.

40545: Phage the Untouchable.author: ColossusofSardia
40545: Phage the Untouchable.text_parsed:
Wow this card has a lot of potential and is fun in a zombie deck. Though in a deck built around her it is possible to win with her by turn 4 without even using her to attack with cheap cards;

Starting Hand, 3 Dark Ritual, 1 Phage the Untouchable, 1 Endless Whispers, 1 Swamp and 1 Mountain.

Start turn one playing the swamp, drawing another swamp. Then turn two by playing the mountain, throw down a dark ritual to play Endless Whispers and also drawing a terminate. Throw down the last swamp on turn three and then use dark ritual twice to play Phage. At this point it does not matter what you do because you terminate her on turn 4 sending her to your graveyard which in turn forces her into play from your graveyard under your opponents control making him loose the game.

Of course you could just pull of a turn two win and play her on turn one with two black lotus, 1 swamp and attack on turn two.

@Dragon Whelp
Silliness aside, I think that when they lose the first time, they are no longer in the game and thus combat with them/their creatures ceases after the First Strike Combat Step (when someone gets priority) and thus the opponent loses right there. Your second strike never hits I'm fairly sure.

This is actually relevant btw! Because if you have Lifelink or similar, you'll only get the first hit (not both) when it comes to multiplayer.

40545: Phage the Untouchable.author: Ferlord
40545: Phage the Untouchable.text_parsed:
Thanks to the way my local card store runs EDH tourneys, I can always have a sure 4-points each game, since every time you kill a player, you get 2 points. It doesn't matter if it's you or not: someone got the 2 points by Ancient Tombing himself

I'm going to plan to play a terribly defensive and pathetic deck that annoys rather than destroys. It will include Oppression, Jinxed Idol, Subversion, Syphon Flesh, Syphon Mind, Phyrexian Obliterator...

All of the cringe-worthy spells that'll make my opponents happy rather than sad that I killed myself.

See, usually, most people get 2-3 points in the end. This way, I can at least get third or fourth.

... Then again, it kind of defeats the purpose of going to a tournament in the first place...

42017: Plated Sliver.author: Ferlord
42017: Plated Sliver.text_parsed:
I think Plated Sliver is the third-brother of Sliver decks: Muscle Sliver and Sinew Sliver overshadow it, but it is still 1 CMC and shares the White colour (which also allows for Talon Sliver and Sidewinder Sliver to get some action).

Personally, I'd rather play this than Virulent Sliver, because when you're playing sliver's, what would you rather have:
A 1/2 (or 2/3 +), or a 1/1 (or 2/2 +) with poisonous 1?

Sure, you can stack poisonous, but when your sliver's are dying to Sanctuary Cat, you have to stop and look at what you're doing with your life... Poison Counters? C'mon...

42017: Plated Sliver.author: james2c19v
42017: Plated Sliver.text_parsed:
Sidewinder Sliver overshadows this, because instead of giving your slivers +0/+1, it gives your opponents' creatures -1/-1 when they block. Not only is that better numbers for you, but it actually kills creatures with 1 toughness before combat even starts.

Obviously this is good by itself as a 1/2 for 1 that pumps your other slivers, but unless you're doing mono-white slivers, there probably isn't any room for extra 1-drops beyond Sidewinder and Virulent Sliver.
42017: Plated Sliver.text_posted:

Obviously this is good by itself as a 1/2 for 1 that pumps your other slivers, but unless you're doing mono-white slivers, there probably isn't any room for extra 1-drops beyond Sidewinder and [autocard]Virulent Sliver[/autocard].

42025: Essence Sliver.author: ClockworkSwordfish
42025: Essence Sliver.text_parsed: Quite possibly my favourite Sliver. for a 3/3 lifelinker isn't bad (Vampire Nighthawk makes them all look bad, I know) and it's very good for a Sliver. Once you get it in play, an army of lifelinkers is a force to be reckoned with; if the opponent does manage to kill Essence Sliver, you will still be most likely looking at double-digit life gains easily if this wasn't killed early, and it IS a 3/3 body, which is about as big as Slivers get (Battering Sliver and the various WUBRG leaders are exceptions, obviously). Plus, the art is excellent. Bottom line: Economical price, extremely powerful ability, tough body, great art. 5/5 to the best of the Slivers. As soon as I get $5, I'll get one.

42028: Frenetic Raptor.author: Zuty
42028: Frenetic Raptor.text_parsed:
Zuty's Random Card of the Day #2:

6 for a 6/6 isn't that bad; of course there are better options, some of which are cheaper in cost, but 5C for a 6/6 is rather easy to deal with.

I have fond memories of this card just because of the art and flavor text. I don't think I ever played with this card or made a deck that contained it. I'm sure I could put this to good use in Poor Man's (5 uncommon, 55 commons), but there are some other uses I see for this. It stops ALL Beasts from blocking. So you can stop Beasts your opponent is using from blocking, but how often is that? Well, with cards like Amoeboid Changeling, Conspiracy, Imagecrafter, and Unnatural Selection that can all be changed. You can also use Artificial Evolution (put it on Isochron Scepter if you want) to change 'Beast' to whatever else you want.

Even with this small amount of good that can be done with this card, there are WAY better cards out there. This card has some GREAT art and even better flavor text, but I would have MUCH rather have had this just been a vanilla 6/6 for .

1.5/5

~Zuty

42038: Toxin Sliver.author: jilting_joker
42038: Toxin Sliver.text_parsed:
Powerful sliver card right here, I give it a 4 out of 5.
Toxin Sliver + Talon Sliver + Hunter Sliver = Destroy any target creatures an opponent controls, even if they are tapped (unless they have first strike or double strike), they cannot be regenerated.
By giving slivers first strike and provoke along with Toxin Sliver's ability, attacking slivers would kill blocking creatures before taking any combat damage from those blockers. Talon Sliver and/or Fury Sliver combo very nicely with Toxin Sliver.

If you like playing deathtouch-like abilities, I recommend building a sliver deck around this card. However, Toxin Sliver's text is not exactly equal to a card with deathtouch. The "deathtouch" keyword is written out as: "Any amount of damage this deals to a creature is enough to destroy it." Toxin Sliver must deal "combat" dammage (attack dammage) to destroy creatures, whereas a card with deathtouch could be equipped with a card like Viridian Longbow to destroy target creature by tapping. See what I mean? If an opponent plays a card that prevents you from attacking or dealing combat dammage, Toxin Sliver is rendered useless. That weakness is why I vote a 4 instead of 5 on this card.

By giving slivers first strike and provoke along with Toxin Sliver's ability, attacking slivers would kill blocking creatures before taking any combat damage from those blockers. Talon Sliver and/or Fury Sliver combo very nicely with Toxin Sliver.

42041: Magma Sliver.author: Mode
42041: Magma Sliver.text_parsed:
Right. Either try Horned Sliver on the precedent turn, or when not running green consider using the more expensive red alternative, Battering Sliver. Although to be honest i would refuse from using the latter one in general since he's simply overcosted.
Same here with Synchronous Sliver, although when playing blue you could add a Shifting Sliver, which makes yours effectively unblockable. Then they could tap for themselves after attacking to double their power. If you run a Fury Sliver as well then your Slivers will hit your opponent with a pretty nasty double strike.
A simple first strike from the cheap white Talon Sliver sould do a good job with Magma Sliver.

42041: Magma Sliver.author: PolskiSuzeren
42041: Magma Sliver.text_parsed:
The very definition of alpha strike. by the time this guy is down, you should already have the haste, mana, and flying slivers in play, if not more.

T1: metallic.
T2: gemhide, tap metallic for another metallic (or any one drop sliver)
T3: Heart, winged, Magma
T4: Legion, swing with legion (13/13), pump with 5 of your others (one was used to cast him) for 7 per pump, grand total of 48 in the air.

Gotta love slivers. Yeah, it's a god hand and a god draw, but I've pulled similar situations frequently.

42041: Magma Sliver.author: Barry1189
42041: Magma Sliver.text_parsed:
This guy pairs beautifully with essence sliver from the same set. you usually gain more life than your opponents can take off you.

That being said, there are situations where you wouldn't want to use him, which makes him more flexible than sliver legion e.g. when you want to hit with lots of slivers for brood sliver or synapse sliver, which admittedly would be to use this guy.


@grimjawx rules: use ward sliver instead. sure, it's not impenetrable like crystalline, but played right it will keep spot removal at bay. Also, does the job of shifting sliver as well leaving an extra slot for yet another finisher.

42041: Magma Sliver.author: Pongdok
42041: Magma Sliver.text_parsed: Don't pass on Crystalline just because of this guy. They have plenty of friends that let you sacrifice something with an inconvenient ability at an opportune moment. Better yet, use Hibernation Sliver to pop Crystalline into your hand when one of your pretties gets through, then start tapping down for Magma's ability until someone dies. If it gets fogged, replay your Crystalline and try again next turn. Slivers are patient. 5/5

Give me one good reason why she is not good. She's arguably one of the best creatures in Magic's long history. The 8 mana could be a turn-off for some, but otherwise she's one fantastic beatstick. 5/5 all day, every day.

42049: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.author: Pongdok
42049: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.text_parsed: To animate her, you don't use a black enchantment. They fall off, and she goes right back where she came from. (You could waste a card doing Sleight of Mind, or something, but you won't.) In a regular deck, if you haven't already lost by the time she shows up to the party, your opponent deserves what's coming. Pretty intimidating, but still mortal. Iona and Avacyn are dumb. Linvala, too, if you're keeping score. Old angels forever. 5/5

42064: Gempalm Sorcerer.author: DarthParallax
42064: Gempalm Sorcerer.text_parsed:
Actually, in some ways, this is the best Gempalm card. No, I'm being serious. It takes a while to accept the potentials, but consider:

"Wizard" is probably the most common type after "Human" (I think?) Don't think about this like a Green-Red Mage, who wants all their creatures to be 4+/4+ and have trample if they are striking-- think of this as your BETA plan, not your ALPHA one--

Check out all those Power 2 or less Wizards. They are pretty great cards. There's at least one Wizard Lord (though I forgot the name) AND of all the CLASS types, WIZARDS is the easiest to 'break into' with RACE Lords-- ie ELF Wizards, GOBLIN Wizards, HUMAN Wizards, ZOMBIE Wizards, MERFOLK Wizards...I think even BIRD Wizards exist and have a Bird Lord. Here is how I would suggest using Gempalm Sorceror to best effect:

U/R/G Riku of Two Reflections or U/B/R Nicol Bolas. Usually Nicol Bolas wants to play as much power as you can muster, but for flavorful funsies, what about making a Commander Deck ALL about his little minions that he coordinates?

Once you start thinking in terms of Three-Color Commander Decks and discover that it's of relatively little opportunity cost to play, say, Goblin Cheiftain and a bunch of Goblin Wizards or Ambush Commander and a bunch of Elf Wizards next to your Mono Blue Wizards, then while this guy might not be Insane, he also looks, to me anyway, clearly better than the Green and White Gempalm cards. (The Green one is honestly good, but I feel confident that Elves can just plain do better if they want to increase their attack points.)
42064: Gempalm Sorcerer.text_posted:
Actually, in some ways, this is the best Gempalm card. No, I'm being serious. It takes a while to accept the potentials, but consider: 

"Wizard" is probably the most common type after "Human" (I think?) Don't think about this like a Green-Red Mage, who wants all their creatures to be 4+/4+ and have trample if they are striking-- think of this as your BETA plan, not your ALPHA one--

Check out all those Power 2 or less Wizards. They are pretty great cards. There's at least one Wizard Lord (though I forgot the name) AND of all the CLASS types, WIZARDS is the easiest to 'break into' with RACE Lords-- ie ELF Wizards, GOBLIN Wizards, HUMAN Wizards, ZOMBIE Wizards, MERFOLK Wizards...I think even BIRD Wizards exist and have a Bird Lord. Here is how I would suggest using Gempalm Sorceror to best effect: 

U/R/G [autocard]Riku of Two Reflections[/autocard] or U/B/R [autocard]Nicol Bolas[/autocard]. Usually Nicol Bolas wants to play as much power as you can muster, but for flavorful funsies, what about making a Commander Deck ALL about his little minions that he coordinates? 

Once you start thinking in terms of Three-Color Commander Decks and discover that it's of relatively little opportunity cost to play, say, Goblin Cheiftain and a bunch of Goblin Wizards or Ambush Commander and a bunch of Elf Wizards next to your Mono Blue Wizards, then while this guy might not be Insane, he also looks, to me anyway, clearly better than the Green and White Gempalm cards. (The Green one is honestly good, but I feel confident that Elves can just plain do better if they want to increase their attack points.)

42065: Gempalm Polluter.author: RuthieA
42065: Gempalm Polluter.text_parsed:
Quite possibly one of the most evil Zombie cards in the game. On its own, perhaps it's not so powerful, however in a Zombie deck (particularly ones with Lord of the Undead and Disentomb) it can be deadly. Say your opponent has five zombies in play (if not more, because they probably have raided your graveyard using Cemetery Reaper), and then cycles Gempalm Polluter. You lose five life. The next turn they do it again. Twice, because they have a disentomb in their hand. It's just terrible. If you're playing it, of course, it's a great combo.

That said, this card's main strength is its cycling ability. A 4/3 for 6 Mana is a little costly nowadays, and so, I can't really see this card being played, as such, it basically amounts to an uncounterable two mana sorcery. Which is fine, especially in the right kind of deck (namely one with lots and lots of Zombies).

42065: Gempalm Polluter.author: Carnophage_4ever
42065: Gempalm Polluter.text_parsed:
Hmm, I use these with Lord of the Undead and Grave Pact. It then deals damage to the opposing player while getting rid of his creatures when you cycle it. When your zombie throng is substantially deployed, it's an instant kill.

Seems to me that some people confuse "each zombie" for "each swamp"... Urborg isn't part of a combo with this guy.

For multiplayer I give it a 4.5/5, for duel, a 4/5. The reason is that it's a little bit harder to have a massive zombie legion in play when facing another player alone, who will focus on not letting that happen. If you have less than 5 zombies, it's still worth the cycling, but it wont deal that much damage.

Don't bother trying to play it as a body: if you can afford that, it generally means the game's yours anyway.

42065: Gempalm Polluter.author: corranhorn84
42065: Gempalm Polluter.text_parsed:
@Carnophage_4ever - It's a nice thought, but Grave Pact doesn't work that way.

"Whenever a creature you control is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, each other player sacrifices a creature."

When you cycle Gempalm Polluter, you are activating the Cycling ability on the card, which forces you to discard the card to the graveyard as per its cost. It never went to the battlefield nor was it ever technically a creature, therefore certain conditions were never met. It may have the creature card type, but it's not a creature while in your hand. If you hard cast the card and the spell resolves, then it's a creature on the battlefield and Grave Pact will then take affect.

Also, please look further at the Details rulings above for a clearer understanding on the abilities' activation conditions and the order on the stack, or lack there of.


And if the new text "dies" is on your Grave Pact card...

700.6. The term dies means "is put into a graveyard from the battlefield." It is used only when referring to creatures.
42065: Gempalm Polluter.text_posted:
@Carnophage_4ever -  It's a nice thought, but [autocard]Grave Pact[/autocard] doesn't work that way.

"Whenever a creature you control is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, each other player sacrifices a creature."

When you cycle Gempalm Polluter, you are activating the Cycling ability on the card, which forces you to discard the card to the graveyard as per its cost.  It never went to the battlefield nor was it ever technically a creature, therefore certain conditions were never met.  It may have the creature card type, but it's not a creature while in your hand.  If you hard cast the card and the spell resolves, then it's a creature on the battlefield and [autocard]Grave Pact[/autocard] will then take affect.  

Also, please look further at the Details rulings above for a clearer understanding on the abilities' activation conditions and the order on the stack, or lack there of.


And if the new text "dies" is on your [autocard]Grave Pact[/autocard] card...

700.6. The term dies means "is put into a graveyard from the battlefield." It is used only when referring to creatures.

42069: Voidmage Apprentice.author: GordonFreechmen
42069: Voidmage Apprentice.text_parsed:
Well first off this version was printed before split second. So no anyone who rates it less than a 4 is not necessarily missing the point. For this version of the card being a morph counter didn't do a whole lot for it, except be a lot slower than other counter spells.

Second there are a total of 15 split second cards in all of magic. A few of which aren't even playable in competitive formats. And some of the others like Angelic Grace love to be used in decks like Ad Nauseam, in which case it will be going off before you have time to play this card and then pay it's morph cost. Even considering it can counter split second cards. It really isn't worth it as a counter over say Last Word. Which isn't even the best counter. After all this card isn't legal in modern. If you are playing it you could be playing a force of will, a mana drain, a counterspell, daze, etc. Split second isn't too prominent in legacy. You are going to want a faster counter over this. You just are. And the addition of being a 1/1 doesn't really make paying 7 mana for this anymore worth it.

Also I must say that almost everyone I have seen run this. Runs it in a deck with no other morph creatures. I could if I really wanted to play my spell just doom blade this before hand. You can either let it die, or you can flip it to counter the doom blade. Costing you 4 mana to save a 1/1. It just isn't that great. I would never run it.

42077: Dark Supplicant.author: Mode
42077: Dark Supplicant.text_parsed:
He is an awesome fellow, and does an especially great job in a Cleric deck, allowing a Scion of Darkness already in turn 2 if things work out nicely, and later on if you sacrifice your clerics with a Rotlung Reanimator in play you won't regret it either. This guy makes Cleric decks more competitive.

And i think Etregan is right, the Herald cycle from Shards of Alara was likely inspired by this card.
Unfortunately though, as opposed to this goodie, these are pretty useless and boring.
The Heralds do not only require three mana to activate their ability, they need two other creatures of different colors to sacrifice - which is pretty hard to manage, and are even only able to find the card if it's in your library.
I normally like such cards which are able to fetch other cards with a certain name, but the Herald cycle was a poor unplayable cycle of pitious uncommons...may this never happen again.

The obvious cycling synergy is pretty nice. If you don't mind card disadvantage (and you probably don't if you're running this..)

consider dropping the dragon shadow, dragon wings and especially dragon breath into the graveyard. Doing all this with a Putrid imp will require a *very* admirable hand but will allow you to pound early. That said, he's not as good until they have something worth reanimating!

Consider running this guy in {B}{U} with artificial evolution. If you name Spirits then it's easy to run Nether Shadow, Nether Traitor, and Bloodghast to get repeatable Scions no matter what your opponent does!

42078: Shifting Sliver.author: JaxsonBateman
42078: Shifting Sliver.text_parsed:
Obviously good in more mid-rangey sliver decks, that aren't winning off the back of the power early drops of green/white slivers. "All your creatures are unblockable" is pretty powerful.

Personally though, I do enjoy it in my Bant "every-tribe" deck, built primarily around Mirror Entity, and a couple of different tutors to ensure I get out the ME, and any tribal effects I want. Having unblockable creatures when you have a Mirror Entity out is usually savagely brutal.

42172: Crookclaw Elder.author: nullsurface
42172: Crookclaw Elder.text_parsed: This guy's the bird form of Shieldmage Elder, and probably not as good. I suppose if you had both of them out they'd make a weird duo. I feel like the reason this bird wizard costs so much is his ability is essentially unbounded: it's limited only by the number of birds and/or wizards you control (though to be blunt, the wizard ability is junk, even without the existence of cards like Levitation). Ironically, at the time the card was printed, you'd have to just use your other Aven creatures to draw cards, but since then, Bird Token technology has truly "taken off" (har har har). Consider: Flurry of Wings, Emeria Angel, Dovescape, Call, and so forth. So maybe there's hope for your casual white/blue bird deck after all!

42178: Ghastly Remains.author: jazzman20
42178: Ghastly Remains.text_parsed:
This is one of my least favorite cards in Magic. The reason I hate it so much is that it looks like it should be a fun card to play with, right up until you try to use it. It always disappoints when you try to cast it. If you try to make it less disappointing, you only end up hurting your board position by withholding cards. Sure, you could use it as a bad Squee. Or, you could just use Squee and save yourself the headache.

This card looks like it should be fun, but is always disappointing in the CMC to casting cost ratio. It also forces you to do unfun things in order to get even marginal utility out of it. If Wizards' goal was to make this card a "skill tester" they don't need to make skill testers as punishing or unfun as this. A badly implemented card on every level.

42187: Caller of the Claw.author: Mode
42187: Caller of the Claw.text_parsed:
I seriously can't quite remember her being called the best card in Legions by many, given that this set also includes Akroma, Angel of Wrath for instance.

Although i agree that this is a pretty neat card.
Having flash, this is an awesome response to board hosers.
And in general it's also a cheap choice to get two or more 2/2 bodies for just after combat.
Yet i'd preferably play her with an ensured use given by having something to get rid of your creatures.
Permanents that can sacrifice creatures like the aforementioned Nantuko Husk are useful.
Even better if they return another creature like Apprentice Necromancer, Doomed Necromancer or Hell's Caretaker.
If you return another dead Caller of the Claw and produce further tokens.
Therefore Second Sunrise might also be a good choice.

Bouncing it with Wirewood Symbiote might also indeed be a good idea, especially if you have another creature with a handy -ability. To make better use of her a second time (since most of your creatures will be 2/2 bear tokens then which won't trigger her ability) i'd consider playing something like Bloodghast or Nether Traitor.

You could also use Order of Whiteclay, which can return any creature with cmc 3 or less, including Caller of the Claw. The downside is that he requires to be tapped and needs much white mana.
Recurring Nightmare is an even greater variant, which effectively allows triggering any of your creature's cip trigger for by saccing it and returning it again - as often as you wish.

42187: Caller of the Claw.author: heenaheena
42187: Caller of the Claw.text_parsed:
Quite possibly my favorite card. The artwork and flavor rock; if you're a green mage, you gotta love an elf lady dressed as a bear leading a gang of eerie bears, all of whom are ***ed off about creature destruction. and turning your opponents mass removal into an ursine plague wind is awesome. Who cares if your tech creatures just turned into regular 2/2 bears when they're the only things on the board and are ready to smash face. Green needs things to hose mass removal and this may be the best card for it.

Even using it as simply an ashcoat bear for 3 can be useful at times. I once threw it out onto the battlefield to team up with my llanowar elves and block ob nixilis who had not gotten bigger yet. If I hadn't done that, I probably would have lost.

You can even combo caller with your own creature kabooms and sacrifices if you don't think she's relevant enough.

42278: Daru Stinger.author: DarthParallax
42278: Daru Stinger.text_parsed:
while the errata makes it remain basically 'just about playable' today, back in the day it was such a swingy errata change that it actually warped the Limited environment, going from a 2/2 or 3/3 much of the time to a 6/6 or 7/7 much of the time overnight, because of the many creatures to receive Human as an errata'd type. It was suggested by an old article from the period that it should be reset to only affect Soldiers.

I think if that change had been made, it would still be a 2 or more star card today (not over 2.5), and because it's easy to find a lot of Human-Soldiers, a casual deck could still find him a home, but I don't think it was a bad enough decision to not re-errata it that it grossly negatively impacted Magic's History.

Trivia Nerds might like to know little things like this, though. :)
My Vorthos side doesn't really know whether to Like or Dislike his interaction with Human-Werewolves, and ultimately decides that because there are no White Werewolves, it's odd but ok. And playing this next to Mayor of Avabruck is strangely pleasing since Green and White are allied colors. I admit Vorthos would be offended if a person made a Boros deck with this and Mono-Red Werewolves, and it refuses to comment on using it with Huntmaster of the Fells, because it's torn enough to see things either way.

It's pretty good, and a bomb in Limited.

43714: Smokespew Invoker.author: tezcat
43714: Smokespew Invoker.text_parsed: The previous poster is absolutely right. Keep in mind that not all cards in a set are created solely with Constructed formats in mind. I played a ton of OLS (Onslaught, Legions, Scourge) booster draft, and this creature was indeed good. The -3/-3 means straight-up death for many creatures (including pesky regenerators), and when combined at instant speed with combat damage, can help kill even tougher creatures. The Red counterpart, Flamewave Invoker, is strictly better than any vanilla 2/2 for 2R, and was great for getting around late-game creature stalemates. Green's version, Stonewood Invoker, is strictly better than any vanilla 2/2 for 1G, and also helped in the late-game when your opponent could kill most anything else by gang-blocking. These cards also existed in a tribal-themed environment, which meant their subtypes were important and most likely beneficial. Remember, context is everything!

43714: Smokespew Invoker.author: SAUS3
43714: Smokespew Invoker.text_parsed:
@Trygon_Predator
It's a last gasp that doesn't cost you a card, and can be used over and over. Ya, it kills indestructible and regenerating guys, but he can also kill regular guys too. Late game, if you have nothing better to do, killing off their creatures is definitely not useless. It's weak for the cost, but doesn't cost you card advantage, and in fact, generates it. That's a lot to say for a common.

I use this guy in my pauper zombie EDH deck as a late-game bomb. He can pretty much win alone. All the actual removal builds up in your hand while you kill off what you can with this guy, and then when they play something too big, kill it with a removal spell.

He's not amazing, but he's certainly not bad. He's he simple 3/1 for 3 (which isn't that bad for black), and he has great late-game potential.

44210: Nantuko Vigilante.author: Ichorix
44210: Nantuko Vigilante.text_parsed:
Honestly, I think this card is really quite good. Compare it to Viridian Zealot, which got a lot of play in its day:

Viridian Zealot costs 1 less CMC (albeit it requires double green), has a 2/1 body and has an activation cost that requires you to sacrifice it.

Nantuko Vigilante costs 1 CMC more (assuming you paid the morph cost, of course), has the same activation cost, but instead of sacrificing it you gain a nice 3/2 body. Maybe I'm crazy here, but I'd rather take the Vigilante.

Of course, tribal types complicate things, but I still think the advantage is significant.
44210: Nantuko Vigilante.text_posted:

Nantuko Vigilante costs 1 CMC more (assuming you paid the morph cost, of course), has the same activation cost, but instead of sacrificing it you gain a nice 3/2 body. Maybe I'm crazy here, but I'd rather take the Vigilante.

Of course, tribal types complicate things, but I still think the advantage is significant.

44210: Nantuko Vigilante.author: blurrymadness
44210: Nantuko Vigilante.text_parsed:
What ichorix is noting is the difference between a control and an aggro mindset.

Aggro sees Viridian as a means to a T3 arty/enchant hate if necessary, but a beater if not. Control sees this as card advantage and taking card of an artifact T4+. The turn difference is also a problem for things like AEther Vial, not that this sees legacy play.

Also, except in the case where you morph T3 or T4, then go on the payment plan, you'll usually want Acidic Slime since it's a better defender, a comparable attacker, and is guaranteed card advantage.

44276: Noxious Ghoul.author: DoctorKenneth
44276: Noxious Ghoul.text_parsed:
@Arachibutyrophobia:
It makes flavour sense for zombies to be very tribal. When has one lone zombie ever been scary? No, horror movies use the zombie swarm to inspire fear. Zombies hunt in packs, as it were. One zombie may never break down a barricade, but ten? Twenty? A hundred? All working together? No place is safe. Zombies may not KNOW they're working together, but they do.

Not only that, but it's easy to make zombie lords, as they appear all over pop culture. A voodoo-esque priest that commands the undead? That's a lord. As is a necromancer with a leather-bound book (fantasy RPGs, Evil Dead), as is the lone zombie that has gained sentience (Land of the Dead), the special-powered zombie that aids the horde (Left 4 Dead), or even the demonic, zombie controlling entity straight out of Hell. Through the lords, zombies are easily united. So, yeah, tribal zombie makes an appropriate amount of sense.

44286: Goblin Firebug.author: Aquillion
44286: Goblin Firebug.text_parsed:
The Bazaar Trader combo isn't an entirely bad idea, since both cards are goblins and there are enough goblin searchers to actually make it work reliably.

It's still not worth it, though, since you have to kill the Firebug.

Hmm. Maybe with Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker and Bazaar Trader? Copy it with Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker, give the copy to your opponent with Bazaar Trader. It's three cards, but again, it's all goblins, so you can easily tutor it up with the various goblin searchers. The problem is that I don't think the copy dies if your opponent has control of it -- Kiki-Jiki says that you sacrifice it, and if you no longer control it, you simply can't.

(Now I'm thinking of better cards to use the Kiki-Jiki / Bazaar Trader combo with.)

@Moleland: Making each player sacrifice a land would actually have been very overpowered, even without any combos. It would have been like Strip Mine on a 2/2 body -- just fill your deck with cheap two-mana goblins, run four copies of this and some other land destruction, and watch as slower decks find themselves completely unable to compete with you.

44299: Havoc Demon.text_parsed:
I dare anyone to try and Rite of Replication this. It'd be awesome to see that and sac this guy causing a massive -30/-30 to all creatures.

For the sake of collecting demons and some safety, this guy is good in a deck that runs mainly 6/6 style demons with the capability to sac. On that note, i'd suggest Carnifex Demon, Hellcarver Demon, and probably Liege of the Pit. Grinning Demon works as well.

These specifically have managable costs (I find that 6 cost or less is easy. 7 cost becomes a bear) and have some synergy (such as hellcarver or the leige killing your havoc demon and subsequently everything else on the field)

I love Havoc Demon. One of the pevital characters in my "Everybody Must Dead"-deck.

Fisrt off I'm compelled to say, to all you Angel people, Akromas and Baneslayers are affected by this card's effect because they aren't being targeted a such. That is the distinction between "each", where everything is targeted specificly, and "all" where the effect is global, without specific targets.

Then an tip: Use a Soldevi Adnate to sac your Havoc Demon, then use the mana to play another one!

44306: Skirk Alarmist.author: Laguz
44306: Skirk Alarmist.text_parsed:
Forms a sweet casual combo with Imperial Hellkite. A 6/6 flyer that swings on turn 4 is something special, especially since it tutors itself up for seconds, thirds and fourths until finally bringing another fat dragon to your hand. When I ran this deck, the chain ended with Quicksilver Dragon, but i'm sure there are a lot of better choices nowadays.

She also combos with dermoplasm to put any creature with morph into play from your hand for free, and the dermoplasm gets bounced to avoid the sacrifice. This was a great way to get those Quicksilver Dragons into play. And Root Elemental is especially potent with this girl...any creature ever printed for free on turn three? Can't go wrong with that...

44323: Planar Guide.author: Mode
44323: Planar Guide.text_parsed:
This is indeed a quite versatile ability.
You might have to do a double-take to note the entire possibilities this card offers. You can:
1. Save creatures from certain spells and/or abilities
2. Trigger cip/etb effects (or "ltb" effects)
3 a) Destroy all tokens (they won't return)
3 b) Destroy all auras (they get destroyed after becoming unattached)
4. Unattach all equipment
5. Prevent your opponent from attacking
6. "Restore" each creature
- they all enter untapped
- all damage on them is removed
- additional counters or similar enhancements are lost as well

A combo with Soul Warden, Master Apothecary, Ancestor's Prophet, Loxodon Hierarch or Orzhov Pontiff might be especially useful since they synergize in Cleric tribal decks.

44324: Wall of Hope.author: SleetFox
44324: Wall of Hope.text_parsed:
A very fun card that differs attackers quite easily. Its utility as a wall is great since while it dies, it heals you, practically blocking two attacks. It's quite potent for only 1 mana. A Steel Wall is a possible alternative, but most of the time I'd rather have this.

It's also a boon in multiplayer in my group. I use three in my all-white deck, and whenever I get one in my opening hand I can almost guarantee that I won't get attacked for most of the game.

44328: Sunstrike Legionnaire.author: sonorhC
44328: Sunstrike Legionnaire.text_parsed:
@Soulcakeduckling: How is an infinite combo that'll win you the game on the turn it goes off "doesn't combo very well"? You tap him to make an elemental, the elemental coming into play causes him to untap. You wait for the untap trigger to finish resolving, and then do it again. And again. And again. Then you attack with all of them. It's not just once per turn.

And even if you already had the Elemental Mastery on some other creature (with a higher power), it still untaps it multiple times. When the tokens (let's say there are four of them) come into play, the Legionnaire's ability triggers and goes on the stack four times. Tap him to lock something down, then wait for one of the triggered abilities to resolve and untap him. Then tap him again, and wait for the second one to resolve and untap him again, and so on.
44328: Sunstrike Legionnaire.text_posted:
@Soulcakeduckling:  How is an infinite combo that'll win you the game on the turn it goes off "doesn't combo very well"?  You tap him to make an elemental, the elemental coming into play causes him to untap.  You wait for the untap trigger to finish resolving, and then do it again.  And again.  And again.  Then you attack with all of them.  It's not just once per turn.

And even if you already had the [autocard]Elemental Mastery[/autocard] on some other creature (with a higher power), it still untaps it multiple times.  When the tokens (let's say there are four of them) come into play, the Legionnaire's ability triggers and goes on the stack four times.  Tap him to lock something down, then wait for one of the triggered abilities to resolve and untap him.  Then tap him again, and wait for the second one to resolve and untap him again, and so on.

44328: Sunstrike Legionnaire.author: Mode
44328: Sunstrike Legionnaire.text_parsed:
Goblin Sharpshooter also has the same trigger as him. Obviously in conjuction with a more synergizing activated ability, but it's still a good trigger.

Pyrostatic Pillar for example is also a famous sideboard choice that triggers under the same circumstances. I admit it's more efficient since it causes damage immediately and red or black can hardly respond to it since it's an enchantment.

But in the case of Sunstrike Leginnaire, you can also run many spells with low cost without any problems - they can even help you untapping the Leginnaire.

This guy proved to be surprisingly efficient against Goblin decks. Only downside is his 2 toughness, so he doesn't find much use as a blocker the turn it still has summoning sickness.
But haste doesn't help Goblins much in their valuable first turns if a creature they cast also means a creature gets tapped. Goblin Incinerator or Tarfire screw your plans though. Unless you have something like Whitemane Lion or Stonecloaker, in which case you'll be able to tap another creature in response to them entering the field (ready to tap an attacker) and the removal fizzles. (These are somewhat efficient against aggro with Shield Sphere or Wall of Omens.)
The Leginnaire also synergizes with Order of Whiteclay and Sky Hussar's Forecast ability.

Compared to Exalted Angel, i don't quite get why skipping an entire turn was necessary:
Exalted Angel can be cast for throughout two turns, she can notably even already see the light of day on turn four and stays a 4/5 flyer with oldschool lifelink permanently.
For Unstable Hulk's trigger you have to pay in total throughout two turns, which rewards you with an 8/8 trampler the turn (likely the fifth one) you pay the remaining cost, and a 2/2 creature on each precedant turn (as you used to have before).

44405: Unstable Hulk.author: Haliax
44405: Unstable Hulk.text_parsed:
Use with Chromeshell Crab and Break Open or Ixidor, Reality Sculptor. Give them a morphed down creature in exchange for something better, flip the Unstable Hulk up on your turn, and make them lose a turn. You could probably make it a repeating effect with other effects that turn a creature with morph face down.

Outside of that admittedly ideal situation, I wouldn't use it. I don't think it'll be worth losing a turn for, most of the time.

44492: Drinker of Sorrow.author: Equinox523
44492: Drinker of Sorrow.text_parsed:
The obvious comparison here is Phyrexian Negator. Here's a quick analysis of pros and cons:

Pros:
- Sacrifice occurs only when it deals combat damage
- Only one sacrifice per packet of damage
- No negative side effect to getting damaged

Cons:
- Can't block
- 3 toughness instead of 5
- Lacks trample

I wouldn't say one is necessarily better than the other, but it boils down to preference. That said, 5 toughness and trample are highly relevant, as this might get chump blocked forever (costing you tons of permanents).
44492: Drinker of Sorrow.text_posted:
The obvious comparison here is [autocard]Phyrexian Negator[/autocard].  Here's a quick analysis of pros and cons:

[b]Pros:[/b] 
- Sacrifice occurs only when it deals combat damage
- Only one sacrifice per packet of damage
- No negative side effect to getting damaged

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Can't block

- Lacks trample

I wouldn't say one is necessarily better than the other, but it boils down to preference.  That said, 5 toughness and trample are highly relevant, as this might get chump blocked forever (costing you tons of permanents).

44496: Beacon of Destiny.author: Internet_decks_lame
44496: Beacon of Destiny.text_parsed:
This card's rating is kind of low... Considering not much feedback either...

Well here is some food for thought. 1/3 body for 2cmc is really not too bad. Having 3 toughness will come in handy and may allow this guy to block something and still throw his absorb at another source. Not to mention this little cleric may force an opponent to use a removal spell, especially if combined with Mother of Runes. Now any fattie, or even direct burn can be absorbed easily. Redirect your damage to beacon, give beacon protection from the color of the damage. You can even absorb the mighty progenitus with this combo, you don't need to sac anything or tap any mana for these abilities either.

I guess I will continue by adding; White has so many 1 (cmc) or 2 (cmc) spells that can easily amplify this cleric. Whether your looking for protection from a color, or reviving this with something like Order of Whiteclay. I will not say for sure this creature will ever enter tournament play, but likely not. Although I would not dismiss this card lightly. Abilities to redirect damage have many different avenues that can be explored. This redirect costs nothing more then a tap.

44656: Goblin Assassin.author: kiseki
44656: Goblin Assassin.text_parsed:
He has to be behind the curve, or else the spikes get uncomfortable. Tournament players will play luck cards if the expectancy is high enough, so the developers tend to price them well out of range so that the tournament scene rewards skill rather than luck.

With Siege-Gang Commander, the expectancy is that each player will lose two creatures, but your two are just goblin tokens that the commander made. Mogg War Marshal is also effective, and Goblin Assault is crazy. You might want Kyren Negotiations to protect the assassin from being forced to attack.
44656: Goblin Assassin.text_posted:
He has to be behind the curve, or else the spikes get uncomfortable.  Tournament players will play luck cards if the expectancy is high enough, so the developers tend to price them well out of range so that the tournament scene rewards skill rather than luck.  

With [autocard]Siege-Gang Commander[/autocard], the expectancy is that each player will lose two creatures, but your two are just goblin tokens that the commander made.  [autocard]Mogg War Marshal[/autocard] is also effective, and [autocard]Goblin Assault[/autocard] is crazy.  You might want [autocard]Kyren Negotiations[/autocard] to protect the assassin from being forced to attack.

44656: Goblin Assassin.author: Lancer873
44656: Goblin Assassin.text_parsed:
Let's take a moment to appreciate the fact that this goblin, this humble 2/2 goblin, can kill literally any creature in Magic. Since it's sacrificing, even indestructible creatures can't get around his wrath.

Tajic? No problem.

Griselbrand? Piece of cake.

Gigantic Wurm? Just gotta know the right place to stab it!

A towering colossus of blightsteel that can kill a planeswalker in one hit? Oh please, he's got more than just a knife!

Eldrazi legends that are often mistaken for gods and can make any mortal go insane with the slightest glance? Pshaw! This assassin has had far tougher challenges! Like taking out his target amidst a crowd. God help him if your target is in a crowd...

... Also God help the crowd.

44840: Dreamborn Muse.author: Equinox523
44840: Dreamborn Muse.text_parsed:
Part of a cycle in Legions later reprinted in Tenth Edition:

: Windborn Muse
: Dreamborn Muse
: Graveborn Muse
: Lavaborn Muse
: Seedborn Muse

I find this an oddball kind of card. It mills indirectly, and encourages opponents to empty their hands for fear of being milled. I suppose you can use stuff like Prosperity to make players draw a lot, but this also runs the risk of giving them the answers they need to derail your strategy. Nowadays something like Jace's Erasure lets you have your cake and eat it too.
44840: Dreamborn Muse.text_posted:

44841: Graveborn Muse.author: Silverware
44841: Graveborn Muse.text_parsed:
This card can be a key player in a zombie deck. While you do have to be careful not to kill your self by using it at the wrong time, the real beauty of this card is that it excelerates your game imensly, and if you are playing heavy aggro zombies the 3/3 body coupled with your other forces (often lords to boost it by at least +1/+1) you may very well kill your opponents before they can shut down your Graveborn Muse.

If all goes well you never even need an answer for all the life you are loosing, usaly you will have made your final stand before that becomes relivant. But if you are worried about the life you will lose, keep a fleshbag or carrion feeder in hand (or in the worst case a nameless inversion).

Basicly this card will give you tons of card advantage. Card advantage your opponents can not ignore.

In a mono-black zombie deck this card screams suicide black, and let me tell you; Few cards do justice to suicide black like Graveborn Muse.

45121: Timberwatch Elf.author: Aaron_Forsythe
45121: Timberwatch Elf.text_parsed:
Aaron’s Random Card Comment of the Day #68, 3/30/11

The Onslaught and Legions teams took an interesting tack with regards to cards with tribal interactions--they only had a small number of them at common, but they tended to make them really good. There weren’t many common in that block that told you to draft a deck of all one creature type, but the ones that did—Sparksmith, Daru Stinger, Timberwatch Elf—hoo boy.

In fact, there isn’t another green common in Legions that even mentioned “Elf” or “Elves” in its text box (Lorwyn had three for comparison). If you didn’t open or draft a Timberwatch Elf in limited, chances are you weren’t that interested in making an Elf deck.

Cards like this need to exist for constructed play--both competitive and casual. Mánaless activations help creature decks keep up pressure, and the scaling nature of the card can make for brutally fast starts that can be impossible for some decks to recover from. We’re typically happy when Elf decks are good in constructed—Elves are beloved by many, many players, and they tend to have a pretty straightforward plan of attack that people of any skill level can appreciate—so I think Timberwatch Elf is a good card to exist.

I just don’t like it at common. All the reasons that make it viable as a constructed card make it oppressive as a limited card. Creatures that repeatedly can pump attackers or blockers can completely paralyze the opponent’s forces. You can’t profitable block anything and can rarely attack on the ground any time a Timberwatch is active on the other side of the board. On top of that, less skilled players walk into the on-board tricks these cards present all the time, making them feel dumb in the short term and making them gunshy about ever attacking with anything on complicated boards. We’ve really shield away from making common cards that do this at all recently—no more Kabuto Moths or Nantuko Disciples in the past few years—let alone ones that scale.

I hold that Timberwatch Elf at common was a format-defining mistake, one we’ve been careful to not come close to repeating.
45121: Timberwatch Elf.text_posted:
[b]Aaron’s Random Card Comment of the Day #68, 3/30/11[/b]

The [i]Onslaught [/i]and [i]Legions [/i]teams took an interesting tack with regards to cards with tribal interactions--they only had a small number of them at common, but they tended to make them really good. There weren’t many common in that block that told you to draft a deck of all one creature type, but the ones that did—[autocard]Sparksmith[/autocard], [autocard]Daru Stinger[/autocard], Timberwatch Elf—hoo boy.

In fact, there isn’t another green common in [i]Legions [/i]that even mentioned “Elf” or “Elves” in its text box ([i]Lorwyn [/i]had three for comparison). If you didn’t open or draft a Timberwatch Elf in limited, chances are you weren’t that interested in making an Elf deck.

Cards like this need to exist for constructed play--both competitive and casual. Mánaless activations help creature decks keep up pressure, and the scaling nature of the card can make for brutally fast starts that can be impossible for some decks to recover from. We’re typically happy when Elf decks are good in constructed—Elves are beloved by many, many players, and they tend to have a pretty straightforward plan of attack that people of any skill level can appreciate—so I think Timberwatch Elf is a good card to exist.

I just don’t like it at common. All the reasons that make it viable as a constructed card make it oppressive as a limited card. Creatures that repeatedly can pump attackers or blockers can completely paralyze the opponent’s forces. You can’t profitable block anything and can rarely attack on the ground any time a Timberwatch is active on the other side of the board. On top of that, less skilled players walk into the on-board tricks these cards present all the time, making them feel dumb in the short term and making them gunshy about ever attacking with anything on complicated boards. We’ve really shield away from making common cards that do this at all recently—no more [autocard]Kabuto Moth[/autocard]s or [autocard]Nantuko Disciple[/autocard]s in the past few years—let alone ones that scale.

I hold that Timberwatch Elf at common was a format-defining mistake, one we’ve been careful to not come close to repeating.

@ Aaron:

First of all, I like Elves, but I liked them at the time of Eladamri, Lord of Leaves. I didn't like Priest of Titania and this continued to this creature as well and ended up with Immaculate Magistrate. So the main problem seems to be the scaling factor.

I don't like cards like this, because they print a "work together" flavor on just one card, rather than really using a "work together" effect. If the TImberwatch Elf would have: "Tap an untapped Elf you control: Target creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn", this would have really got my love (like Field Surgeon vs. Battlefield Medic).

And at your comment about the common Moth & Nantuko, please note Infantry Veteran, Kithkin Daggerdare and co.

45132: Deftblade Elite.author: Kirbster
45132: Deftblade Elite.text_parsed:
I believe the Elite is the best 1-drop soldier printed to date, and is a great 1-drop in general any day.
Rare, indeed, is a 1/1 for one mana with two great abilities that interact nicely.

Provoke is a very powerful creature ability. Early on, you'll be more than willing to trade the Elite for your opponent's Llanowar Elves/Smokebraider/Ballyrush Banneret/whatever to slow him right down and basically put your opponent a turn behind. And of course, since it's provoke, tapping the creature for mana won't save it. If he's using Birds of Paradise, at that point you almost feel bad for him....
Plus, provoke will only get better as the game goes on. With all sorts of lords like Daru Warchief and Field Commander running around, the Elite will get to a respectable size fast and suddenly be able to eat an opposing creature every turn. Just one Warchief makes him into a 2/3, big enough to take out one of those ubiquitous 2/2 first strikers and live.

Gustcloaking for two mana is also a nice bonus. The Elite can eternally block your opponent's biggest creature for just two mana a turn - not a problem if you're setting up in the early game or exchanging lethal blows in the late.

But wait, you can even combine the two! Late in the game, you can attack with your entire army, have the Elite provoke your opponent's most troublesome blocker to keep your other soldiers safe, and even pay two mana to make him live to do it again!

Soldier decks (as well as white weenie in general) have many good options in the 1-drop slot, often relying on creatures with great efficiency from turn one. The Elite beats nearly all of them out, however, by trading sheer numerical efficiency for powerful utility.

45132: Deftblade Elite.author: KadanJoelavich
45132: Deftblade Elite.text_parsed: This guy and my Stonehewer Giant saved my ass when my equipment deck went up against a powerful artifact deck. Despite my early gains with fast attacks, my opponent had double Tinkered for a Darksteel Forge and a Platinum Angel, and on top of that was pounding me every turn with a fatty (and indestructible) Master of Etherium which I was blocking with the Deftblade and just barely holding off with its ability. This stalemate lasted until I got my Stonehewer out, and tutored in my Sword of Kaldra onto the Deftblade, provoked his Angel, and bam: exiled. A truly fantastic way to deal with indestructible creatures.

45133: Brontotherium.author: DoctorKenneth
45133: Brontotherium.text_parsed:
Baconradar: It's actually not as bad as you make it out to be. Remember that this is green, and removal is (and should be) scarce. This is a very good facimille of removal (repeatable, at that), so I'd take value in that. Otherwise, mono-green has no other way of dealing with pesky utility creatures. Well, unless they fly.

Provoke isn't exactly clunky here, either. It means that if your opponent wants to kill him via blocking, he better be prepared to lose the creature you throw in front of it as well (ie, attacking into a 3/3 and 2/2- you provoke the 2/2, forcing him to use his other creature if he wants to get rid of this thing). The (very valid) problem I think you have is his relative fragility. I hear you. But remember he was printed in a block full of creatures- Onslaught block was a tribal block, which meant lots of Lords and piddly utility creatures for him to trample over. That was and is is function. And he's good at it.

He begs to be run with creature pump to make the most of the Provoke/trample combo. Frankly, I love the idea of taking out a creature AND damaging your opponent for a moderate amount without having to do anything else fancy. But with a few Giant Growth-like effects, this is, as has been said, a win condition.

Again, as with most cards of this era, I think modern eyes spoil the value. If printed today, yes, it would probably be five or even four mana (though probably triple green if it went that low).

Ultratog: I think the point of it's inclusion was to repeatably target key creatures, not draw all blockers in for an elf-fuelled Overrun. Though that is a tried and true strategy. But besides, Legions/Onslaught/Scourge had some nice Elf/Beast interactions. It works well enough for casual, I'm sure.

45838: Aven Warhawk.author: OpeeFomenom
45838: Aven Warhawk.text_parsed:
In a sense, Nib is correct. The answer is on the card. Here's the answer in a less dickish manner:

The line in the reminder text that says and/or means that cards that are both birds and soldiers add only one. The "and " part means cards that are birds and soldiers and the "or" part means cards that are either birds or soldiers. Either way, you get 1 counter per card, never 2. So this would have 3 +1/+1 counters and be a 5/5.

In a sense, Nib is correct. The answer is on the card. Here's the answer in a less dickish manner:

The line in the reminder text that says and/or means that cards that are both birds and soldiers add only one. The "and " part means cards that are birds and soldiers and the "or" part means cards that are either birds or soldiers. Either way, you get 1 counter per card, never 2. So this would have 3 +1/+1 counters and be a 5/5.

46457: Skirk Drill Sergeant.author: Ideatog
46457: Skirk Drill Sergeant.text_parsed:
At first glance, it seems nice- recycling your goblins into either more goblins or less lands in your way. However, you have to pay 3 for that, and most good goblins cost less than 3. Siege-Gang Commander, maybe, you'll usually be getting the creature at a loss and you don't have a choice AND you aren't casting it so you can't kick it (I'm looking at you, Goblin Bushwhacker).

Once you get past that, there's a lot of combo potential here. Goblin Bombardment is a good sac outlet and damage dealer, add in Mana Echoes and a red filter and you can blow through every goblin in your deck! Also note that you can activate the ability off of tokens- sac them to Siege-Gang and replace.
